DOC.HEAD: New Leaders Backed, But Some Say Mistake Not To Publicly Try Ceausescus

Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with British recognition, Iran dismissing ambassador, Soviets calling execution an internal affair; picks up 12th pvs, `On Monday...'; Minor editing thereafter to CONFORM
DOC.TEXT: China and Iran, which had cordial ties with Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, today joined countries including the United States and Soviet Union that have pledged support for Romania's new leadership. But the United States and some other governments regretted that Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, who were executed in Romania on Monday after a secret military trial, were not tried publicly. The Soviet Foreign Ministry called the executions an internal affair. Spokesman Vadim Perfiliev said the decision ``has probably been made taking into account the aspirations and will of the Romanian people.'' The Dutch government said it was ``concerned'' that the Ceausescus had been executed after a secret trial and expressed hope that ``the high principles of the rule of law will find their place in the new Romania for which so many have fought to the utmost.'' In Britain, a Foreign Office spokesman said normal accepted standards were difficult during ``a civil war situation.'' ``Although one may regret a secret trial, at the time it was not really surprising,'' said a Foreign Office spokesman, who by custom was not identified. ``Dracula Executed,'' blared the banner headline in Britain's Daily Mirror. ``Tyrants are Executed,'' said the rival Daily Express. Britain, China, Greece and Iran today joined at least 13 other nations in pledging support for Romania's provisional government, which took over after Ceausescu fled the capital in a helicopter on Friday. The Beijing government also said the Red Cross Society of China would provide immediate humanitarian aid, but it did not elaborate. Ceausescu was esteemed by Chinese leaders for maintaining good relations with Beijing over the decades when China and the rest of the Soviet bloc viewed each other with hostility. Ceausescu was one of the few socialist leaders to praise the Chinese leadership's crackdown of the student-led pro-democracy movement in June, when hundreds, perhaps thousands were killed by troops in the streets of Beijing. Iran said today it recognized the Romanian government and Tehran Radio said Iran's Red Crescent Society was ready to send medical aid. But it dismissed its ambassador to Bucharest for failing to inform Tehran of growing opposition to Ceausescu before the Romanian leader visited Iran last week. The United States and France said Saturday they would not oppose Soviet bloc intervention to support Romanians fighting against police units loyal to Ceausescu, but the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said Monday the provisional government had not for Soviet support. On Monday, food and medical aid began to flow into the hard-hit country. French education minister Lionel Jospin said on French television Monday night: ``Perhaps one would have wished that Ceausescu could have been judged and said what he had to say. Naturally we prefer public trials, but these are tragic and at the same time very hopeful events we are seeing now in Romania.'' Philippine President Corazon Aquino said: ``The staggeringly high number of casualties reported in Romania is truly shocking and deplorable. We join the rest of the world in wishing that country and its people the blessings of peace, freedom and well-being.''
